Dima and Owl 
 Traditional San story
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In the old days there were two people, 
 Dima and Owl. 
 Owl owned the sun, water and fire. 
 
 Dima did not have any of these things 
 and lived in darknes with his family. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Dima tried to make a garden, but he
 could not grow vegetables because there
 was no sun. 
 
 Everybody sufered because there was
 no sun. 
 When they hunted animals to eat, they
 
 hung the meat in the tres to dry, but it
 roted because there was no sun.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day, Dima decided to visit Owl. When
 
 they served fod, Dima wondered why
 Owl’s fod tasted so god. He wondered
 if it was because the fod grew in the
 
 sun and it was coked in fire. 
 Secretly, Dima made a plan. He decided
 to dance. He wanted everyone at Owl’s
 
 place to gather around him and se him
 dance. He was a god dancer. Owl and
 
 his family admired the beautiful dancing.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When it grew dark, Owl decided to fetch 
 
 the sun from his house so that he could 
 stil watch Dima’s dancing. 
 Owl kept the sun in an animal skin bag 
 
 inside his hut. He caried the sun out 
 from his house and held it high up above 
 his shoulders. 
 
 Now it was light. Everyone could se far 
 into the distance. Son everyone was 
 
 dancing in the light of the sun. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Dima crept closer to the sun while he
 was dancing. Owl held on to the sun but
 
 after a while he forgot about it because
 he enjoyed the dancing so much. He saw
 how beautifuly Dima danced. He to
 
 wanted to dance like this. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Sudenly, Dima tok his fighting stick 
 and hit the sun into the air like a bal. The 
 sun traveled so far that it remained 
 
 forever in the sky. It gave everyone light 
 al day. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Dima ran away so fast that Owl could not
 
 find him. 
 He stayed far away for a long time. After
 
 a while, he disguised himself and went
 back to Owl’s place. 
 The children recognised him and said:
 
 “There is the man who stole our sun!”
 The adults did not agre with the children
 
 and said, 
 “No, this is not the man who stole our
 sun.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 They saw that this man was an old 
 dancer. He wore a lot of beads around 
 
 his body. They were magic dancing 
 beads and they made people dance. 
 It was not long before everyone was 
 
 dancing. They danced the whole 
 afternon, until the sun began to set. It 
 
 became to dark to se the magic 
 dancer. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Owl said to his wife, “Go and lok in my
 
 bag and fetch the mon.” 
 Owl held the mon high above his
 shoulders and it lit up the darknes for al
 
 to se the dance. While they were
 dancing, Dima moved closer and closer
 
 to the mon, for he had a plan. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He tok his fighting stick and hit the 
 mon high up into the air. Once again, he 
 ran away from Owl. This time he stayed 
 
 away for a very long time, until Owl’s 
 family forgot al about him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Dima disguised himself again and
 
 returned to Owl’s place. 
 This time he wanted Owl’s fire. Owl had
 the firesticks hanging around his neck.
 
 Dima joined Owl under a tre and the two
 men started playing an old claping
 
 game caled gi. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 They claped and claped and as they
 claped some more, Owl’s firesticks
 started jumping around his chest to the
 
 rhythm of the claping. Clap-clap, clap-
 clap. 
 Dima tried to grab the firesticks, but Owl
 
 threw them over his neck so that they
 hung acros his back. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 They claped the whole day long. The rhythm of the claping made Owl
 
 forget al about the firesticks. 
 
 When they swung around onto his chest once more, Dima grabed the 
 
 firesticks and ran away. 
 
 Owl and his family ran after Dima, but he made a clever plan. He had a bag
 
 ful of thorns and threw them onto the ground behind him. This stoped Owl
 and his family from chasing him. They could not cros the thorns on the
 
 path. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Dima could not wait to make fire. He
 rubed and rubed the sticks. He blew
 and blew the ember in a litle dry gras
 
 until a tiny flame apeared. The fire grew
 and lit the whole veld and each time the
 flames reached a tre, Dima said, “From
 
 now on people wil be able to make a fire
 with each tre on earth.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A long time pased. When Dima finaly 
 returned to Owl’s place, he found no one 
 
 but a litle boy playing with woden 
 animals. 
 Dima asked the boy to show him where 
 
 they kept their water. The boy led him to 
 the place of water. Dima saw the big 
 
 djaba, the huge clay pot in which the 
 family stored water. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Dima pretended to leave for his home, but he secretly turned round to the
 place of water. He turned the huge pot over so that the water started flowing
 on the ground. 
 
 Dima quickly jumped over the flowing water to the other side. 
 Then he was safely acros the river of water where Owl could not find him.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 16  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 This is why the whole earth has rivers ful
 
 of water today. 
 This is why we have the sun, mon and
 fire, because of the magician Dima.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 17  
 Story notes 
 
 
 In 203, Katunga Carimbwe told this version of the Dima and Owl origin
 story to Titu Mangumbu and Marlene Winberg in the Northern Cape 
 
 Province of South Africa while he was busy painting on a canvas. 
 Mangumbu, Mahongo and Winberg translated it and retold the story in this
 
 writen version with as few alterations as posible. His elders told the story
 to him during his childhod in Mavinga, Angola, where he was born in 1958.
 Most of the episodes in the Dima and Owl myth have a wide distribution in
 
 the extensive area of southern Africa and the Kalahari whose original
 inhabitants speak !Xun and other closely related languages, although the
 
 names and identities of the trickster, Dima, and his adversary change from
 area to area. 
 The “claping game” mentioned in our version, Dima and Owl, is stil curent
 
 among the !xun, the Nharo, and posibly other comunities of Kalahari San.
 This story depicts Dima as a culture hero and transformer of the primeval
 world into the present world. He achieves this with words, “From now on
 
 people wil be able to make a fire with each tre on earth.” 
 The Manyeka Arts Trust holds a !Xun audio teling of this story by Meneputo
 
 Mnaunga Maneka in archive. 
 
 18 
 The ilustrations in this story are from story boards by Marlene Winberg
 interpreted digitaly by Satsiri Winberg through manipulations of the
 Manyeka Art Colection of paintings made by San artists /Thalu Rumao,
 
 /Tuoi Samcuia and Joao Wene Dikuango, who have al pased away since.
